How I realized that I'm a bad knitter blog

26 February 2013

Last night I sat down and realized it has been over a year since I knit something for myself from a pattern written by someone else. Which, considering that I only knit from patterns by other designers for several years, is a pretty impressive feat. I wasn't trying to do it, and I'm quite sad about it, actually.

My fingers have been itching to knit something quick, small, and fun. I made a Turn A Square for Colin a few days ago. Not only did I fail to notice that I was supposed to change needle sizes, but I also missed a round of increases as well. Whoops. I didn't particularly love the pattern, but that's because I'm not a big fan of plain hats. The decreases are absolutely fabulous, I love every single stitch of this crown.

I browsed through my stash, looking to see if there was something else that I wanted to knit with. But since I just got rid of the bulk of it, there wasn't really much that I could pull from. Lots of random sock yarn that will go into granny square blankets, but not much by way of single skein worsteds or similar.

Using my new stash philosophy, I decided I should go through my Ravelry queue and see what struck me as the perfect project. After finding a pattern I knew I had to make immediately, I took a quick jaunt over to Knit 1 with Kiwi in tow to see what they had by way of worsteds. I had my heart set on a nice gray with a little mustard for the contrast color. I ended up going with something better than mustard.

I plopped on the floor with my puppers and stared longingly at the colorful Anzula Cricket sitting on a shelf left than 10 feet away from me. I love (love, love, love) Anzula yarns. Not only are the amazing and come in great colors, but everyone on the team is amazing. I had the opportunity to meet them at Stitches West in 2012 and they're truly amazing women. So while Kiwi sat on the floor with me and lapped up the attention from all of the knitters, I stared at some yarn and headed home to cast on A Hat for Eudora.

… which I totally, completely, and utterly failed at. First I completely missed the word "provisional," and then I cast on the wrong number of stitches. And then, if that wasn't bad enough, I realized after knitting the contrast hem that I'd been using a needle that was two sizes smaller than called for.

Whoops.

So I'm pretty much a horrible knitter. I don't read every word because I think I know what the pattern is telling me to do, so I make stupid mistakes that cause me to rip out the entire project and completely start over.

But dammit, I will have a pretty hat.

Colors shown: Elephant and Persimmon in Cricket from Anzula.

About pattern purchases

Patterns are sold as downloadable PDF files through Ravelry, with payments processed by PayPal. You do not need an account to use either service.

If you have a Ravelry account, I suggest logging in prior to purchasing so that patterns are added to your library.

Get pattern help

Pattern support is provided free of charge for all of my patterns. We respond as quickly as possible, but sometimes it can take a day or two.

Submit a new help request through Zendesk.

You can also use Zendesk to report errors and ask non-technical questions.

Alternatively, you can try the Ravelry group.

Support is only provided via Zendesk.

FAQ

Can I teach a class using your knitting pattern?

Teaching licensing is temporarily on hold and should resume in 2014.

Can I sell items made using your knitting patterns for profit or charity?

Not at this time.

How do I order wholesale copies for my LYS?

Pattern wholesaling is temporarily on hold and should resume in 2014.

I found an error, how do I report it?

Oh newts! Submit your error through Zendesk and we will fix it.

Happy knitting!
